Posts.Title: Anybody a nurse or doctor? Firelady priz47

Posts.Content: Firelady wrote: I was diagnosed with IDC, 6 x 7 cm tumor, hormone positive (both 90%), grade 2, had neoadjuvant chemo which reduced tumor to 3 x 4.5 cm, double mastectomy, and 33 radiation treatments with BOLUS and 7 boosts.  Prior to surgery I had a SNB.  Five nodes were removed, four were positive.  My official stage is IIIA.  During surgery my surgeon removed a large area of tissue that should have contained lymph nodes.  After surgery he said no nodes were found.  He said it was highly unlikely that I didn't have any nodes in that area, and felt they were not found due to scar tissue from previous SNB.  Is this normal?  I see people have 15 to 30 nodes removed during surgery and they find that I only have 5???  I just need to know if this is normal. Completed DD AC & DD Taxol 6/13/08, Bilateral mastectomy 7/2 followed by radiation. Radiation finished 9/29/08. No reconstruction. Completed Tamoxifen Sept 2013 . Posts.Content: Firelady wrote: I had a dbl mastectomy a year ago.  Cancer was on the left side and they removed nodes.  They also removed the breast on the right side but only because I wanted them to.  No cancer on that side and nodes were not removed.  Two mornings last week I woke up with swelling on the right side of my chest, in the under arm area and towards my upper chest.  Both times the swelling went down and it's only happened once since then.  My onc said it sounded like LE, but no cause for alarm since the swelling went back down.  I was surprised to hear I could have LE on that side.  Has anyone else experienced this on the opposite side?  Just curious...I've always considered the possibility on the cancer side due to node removal, never considered it on the right side. Posts.Content: Firelady wrote: I've finished chemo, just had a double mastectomy, and will start radiation soon.  Does that mean I am cancer free?  This came up the other day when I said something about having BC.  My friend said I didn't have BC anymore because I had been through the surgery and chemo.  I told her I hadn't been told I was cancer free by the doctor and still had radiation to go through.  She said I was considered cancer free after surgery, that radiation was just a follow-up to be sure there weren't any stray cells left behind.  Is this true?  Am I considered cancer free now? Posts.Title: Hardened Area after Radiation Firelady Firelady

Posts.Content: Firelady wrote: I've spent quite a bit of time over the last few weeks reading over this site and several others and noticed it's quite common for BC patients to go thru rounds of chemo, mastectomies and double mastectomies, removal of lymph nodes, radiation, and an abundance of scans on a recurring basis only to have this stuff come back.   I thought chemo killed active cells throughout the body.  If chemo is killing good & bad, how in the world does this stuff keep coming back in other parts of our body?  It scares the devil out of me.  My first dx is at Stage IIIA.  Once I finish chemo, I'll have a dbl mastectomy.  During those surgeries they will remove whatever nodes need to be removed (four positives were found in SNB).  Then I'll do radiation.  I have no family history of cancer, period; but if you look at the evidence, it seems like now that I have it, it's almost a guarantee it's coming back.  It's more like how long before it comes back instead of whether or not it will.  There are too many out there that it's happening to.  Why? Completed DD AC & DD Taxol 6/13/08, Bilateral mastectomy 7/2 followed by radiation. Radiation finished 9/29/08. No reconstruction. Completed Tamoxifen Sept 2013 . Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 03:45AM Firelady wrote: I think I am in a free fall.  I didn't start out this way in January, but seems like the more tests I have, and the more unanswered questions come up (like my liver), the more I tend to spiral.  I want to be strong, upbeat, and courageous.  That's how I started out, please pray that I get it back.  Thanks to all and God Bless You!
Posts.Title: Recurrence ? Firelady Gitane

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 12:22PM Firelady wrote: Hey Ladies, I've been away a while and just checked back in.  I am so grateful for the number of responses since my last post.  I wish I could say I'm doing better overall, but I'm finding that at least in my case it's a day to day process.  Some days I'm constantly fighting the fear, others I just know I'm going to be okay.  I guess maybe that's my new definition of "normal" for right now?  Thanks to all of you and I'll check in with you again soon!
Posts.Title: Recurrence ? Firelady Gitane

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2008 07:05PM - edited Sep 22, 2008 07:06PM by Firelady I had a skin sparing double mastectomy in July because I wasn't sure about reconstruction.  In the time since, I've been leaning heavily on not having it done.  I'm comfortable going flat chested, and I'm comfortable wearing prosthetics.  Typically I've only worn the prosthetics at work since I wear a uniform and work at the fire dept.  I can retire in four years and probably won't wear them after that, I just didn't want people to wonder "what" I was!!  Anyway, should I decide not to do reconstruction, does anyone know if insurance will pay for additional surgery to remove the flaps of extra tissue left under each arm?
